Articles.Content:
Just a tale about obstructive politicans, budget cuts, desperate scientists, loads of red tape, and international politics in my Kerbal universe.

BACKGROUND INFO

Knocker- Slang term for United Provincal Congressman in universe

Office of Ballistic Rocketry (OBR)- Predesscessor to NAA

Vesria- Capitol City of the United Proviences

**** PROLOGUE ****

JUNE 19, 1965

"Dr. Wernher?"

Wernher Von Braun, the middle aged Director of the office of Ballistic Rocketry looked up.. He stared at the Kerbal standing in the doorway of his office without a word or a smile, and motioned for him to come in.

"Yes?"

"I'm Jebediah Kerman. And you are Dr. Wernher, I suppose."

Jebediah figeted nervously. Wernher stared at him coldly, and looked back down at the paper he was reading.

"From the looks of it, you are one of my new interns, or atleast one who's trying to apply for a position as one." He continued. "I have no need for interns here. There is no purpose. Now go home and leave, find yourself a better job. You aren't going to get much of a future here."

Jebediah didn't move. He had been warned by several "old salts" that Wernher was mostly an unforgiving, cold man on the outside, and actively tried to willow down the amount of interns he recieved to make sure only the most loyal and motivated would remain.

He stood his ground.

"Go, go. What makes you think you can do it?"

"I-uh, I read your papers, sir."

"What papers?"

"The one about manned spaceflight sir."

"That one?"

"You predicted that politics would be a barrier to space exploration, and actively fought back against research on an hypersonic military jet plane, saying something along the lines of 'Spend it on a space capsule instead'".

"I sail against the wind and fight the tides." He said gruffly. "Not a good path for career advancement, never is, never will be. Every darned knocker at Vesria got something 'gainst me."

Jebediah stood still.

"Come in, take a seat."

With a deep sigh of relief; Jeb sat down. He had passed the first test; many interns had never made it this far. Wernher looked at him with an mix of respect and distaste, and lit a small cigar. There was a no-smoking rule in the facility, but noone ever said a word about his habits. Atleast for now. The interns at the Ballistic Rocketry office were unoffically dubbed the "Spacenuts", and very few were taken seriously, an fact that frustrated Wernher. Quite often, they were written off as a unoffical government fan club for an popular science fiction movie like "Creatures from Eve" and the "Kerbal Who Conquered Duna", an stigma that the researchers tried their best to avoid. Jebediah himself was a fan of the "Kerbal who Conquered Duna", though he tried his best to hide this fact from his close peers.

Seeing that Jebediah had settled down, Wernher went into his usual grilling in a thick Germanic accent.

"Why do you want to get into aerospace engineering? What the bloody hell compelled you? Its not a profitable industry, and the pay's on the lower end of the scale"

The question caught Jebediah by surprise. He quickly tried to stagger out a answer, but it was too late. Wernher was on the next one.

"Why are you here in my office? Why do you want to work here? This division has no real future for the next ten years. You are a smart young Kerbal, your 4.1 GPA shows that. Why are you wasting your potinetal in this..in this underfunded joke of an agency?"

"I, uh, want to go to space."

Wernher sighed.

"You are not going to space anytime soon."

"But your work is interesting."

"Why?"

"Because Kerbalkind needs to spread into space to survive the next century."

"Ha! You are a funny one. I doubt I'll make it to retirement, and you're talking about the next century." Wernher paused to look at his intern, then continued. "I've seen enough in my bloody life to compensate for an full millenia. And I'm not even that old!"

"I don't care about myself, sir. I want my children too, and if not, my grandchildren. I want them to look back, and say "My ancestors conquered the stars"."

"And whats the chance of that? Considering the current political atomsphere, NEVER. NEVER. NEVER."

"The competition with the Red's, that could be a lucky brea-"

"Nope. Not gonna happen. We just got sidelined by several million, and we only got enough to run one more rocket test launch this year."

"But I still want them to have a chance of living in a spacefaring future. Its not for me, or for you, but for them. My great-grandfather came to the Provineces fifty years ago. He was doing well in his homeland, but here, he struggled with poverty. But before he died, he told me that he did this for me, and that made it all worth it."

And with that, Wernher fell silent. Jebediah knew it had pulled a heartstring or two with him, and so, he waited. There was a deep sigh coming out of Wernher, and he got up.

"You're in. Report to the Assembly Hangar tomorrow at nine."

"Yes, sir."

"And get yourself a cup of coffee on the way out. Hall 4, Room 12, make a left turn at the emergency exit near the enterance corridor."

"Yes, sir."

"And one more thing. Were do you see yourself in ten years?"

Jebediah grinned, and pointed at the ceiling.

"Up there."
